reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s ‘shock test’ that uses a VNM-cardinal scale anchored at extinction=0 and best-feasible=1 to claim it can be rational to prefer a eutopia/extinction gamble over a seemingly wonderful guaranteed future. That point is not the main engine of the essay’s ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion (which is primarily supported by the multiplicative-fragility arguments and the later taxonomy of fussy vs easygoing moral views), so centrality is moderate-low. Still, under moral uncertainty or non-VNM/lexical/incomplete views, the rhetorical inference from “counterintuitive” to “therefore fussy/no easy eutopia is plausible” weakens, so the critique has some bite. It is largely correct that the intuitive comparison depends on a contentious cardinalization/normalization and that Section 3.5 itself emphasizes how normalization can flip recommendations; the critique correctly notes a tension between relying on the intuition pump and conceding scaling arbitrariness. However, it only partially undermines the position because (i) the paper explicitly stipulates VNM representability and brackets incomplete views, so the critique is partly an objection to scope/framings rather than an internal contradiction, and (ii) the core thesis can be maintained even if the ‘60–40’ rhetoric is dropped. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight. Overall impact is limited because it mostly challenges the motivational/rhetorical pressure of one framing rather than the main substantive arguments for futural value fragility/fussiness.
title: Intertheoretic normalization choices make the gamble framing an artifact, not a robust conclusion
